newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Coal & Allied train remains blocked.
newsitem.headline: Coal & Allied train remains blocked.

text.p: Coal and Allied's attempt to use non-union labour to load up a coal train and bypass a union picket line at its strike-bound Hunter Valley Number One mine remained stalled on Monday afternoon.
Coal and Allied's General Manager of Operations at the mine, Allan Davies, said picketers were still blocking the railway track and stopping the train from loading.
"The train is waiting to proceed in to load," Davies told Reuters from the Hunter Valley site.
"The police are tying to clear the line. The train won't proced until the line is clear," he said.
Coal & Allied, 71 percent owned by Rio Tinto Plc/Ltd, has estimated each strike day costs the company about A$1 million in lost revenue.
The strike is now four weeks old.
Coal and Allied's attempt to negotiate more flexible enterprise bargains, the key reason for the strike, is seen a key battle in the industry's drive to improve profitability.
Davies said he was optimistic the train would be allowed to pass the picket line and load up later on Monday.
Police were asking picketers to move off the line, he said.
"I would have expected that's not an unreasonable thing to ask for," he said.
Coal and Allied tried to get the train through the picket line on Friday, but was stopped when the engine driver refused to cross the line.
Meanwhile, Industrial relations mininster Peter Reith said Coal and Allied's attempt to improve productivity was perfectly reasonably.
"In the coal industry we have very low productivity and efficiency levels," Reith told reporters.

"That is costing us nationally both jobs and export income. It is a perferctly reasonable proposotion whether you are an employer or employee to change work practices in the coal industry to boost productivity," he said.
"People are well paid in the coal industry. It is not as if they have been short-changed."
Reith said the government's Workplace Relations Act, which took effect in January, included strong provisions secondary boycotts and primary boycotts.
But Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union National President John Maitland said feeling was strong at the mine.
"This train is going to load coal produce by non-union labour at a time when unionists are conducting legal industrial action," Maitland told Reuters.
He said part of the coal industry's problem was the price settled with overseas buyers.
Maitland said buyers laugh at lack of unity among Australian producers.
"Quite often, they go overseas and cut each other's throats," he said.
Coal and Allied's shares were untraded on Monday, having closed unchanged at A$9.20 on Friday.
Prime Minister John Howard said there may be legal remedies for Coal and Allied under secondary boycott laws, which are designed to stop workers in other industries striking in sympathy.
"There may be remedies available under the secondary boycott laws. They may be able to go to court and get an order that the obstruction be removed."
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
